comment_139:
This song is about your ego - your mind which judges yourself and others, complains about them, cares what other people think, wants to please them to get admiration in return, wants to be above others, makes you feel like a victim if needed, creates "reasoned alibies" for what you do on its behalf. Ego leads you through your life until you discover it exists, the way it operates, and find out that your ego is not you. I've discovered it after reading Eckhart Tolle's "A New Earth", which describes mechanics of ego besides other spiritual stuff. At the same time, Metallica's song Sad but True became understandable like never before.

Ego survives by pretending to be you (âIâm your lifeâ) and keeping you out of being aware of it. Furthermore, stories in your mind about others betraying you and other judgments empower ego through feeling of separateness from others. Ego pretends to be "the one who cares", but it actually only cares about its own survival. You are only its "mask, cover, shelter". Ego also feeds itself on the belief that without it and separation between "me" and others you are not real, so it "makes you real". If you go through life with ego being your eyes, you'll live in "your dream" created by ego and not really living. 

Your ego pushes you to do whatever it thinks it will make it grow more, even bad things, just to enhance itself and separateness from others. You are just its "scapegoat" who does his "dirty work". Then it judges your doings through its eyes (when you must steal)". 

Your ego seeks admiration and love from others. It can never get those from others fully, so it makes you feeling hate because of that - "hate when you want love" - and you "pay the price" by feeling negative emotions, pain. 

When your ego has grown too much and became too arrogant, it stops caring ("I no longer care"), even about being discovered and destroyed. It can even afford to tease you to "come inside and open your eyes". It doesn't care at all, so it's free to impose great suffering on you. Under a great suffering, you start questioning yourself, "looing inside and opening your eyes" and finally see the ego inside you. It says "I'm you", but it can't trick you anymore. The mere fact that there's a separation in that sentence between I and you signals that you are aware that the ego exists as something other than you. Otherwise, the end would have been just "I am." So the song ends with your ego being discovered in light of awareness / consciousness. Ego can't live in presence of consciousness, so it dissolves and you are finally becoming free. Or, you can still live your "dream" through your ego's eyes, always judging and complaining about the world and people, just like the man in My Friend of Misery. And spend the whole life without knowing the truth. Just like the man in the Unforgiven song. But even he at the end takes a look back and realizes the truth.

It's incredible how I previously had thought this song is so depressive, but now it appears so positive, since consciousness wins. Sooner or later.

Also, it looks like those who understand this song as about being about addiction are right. Ego survives by you being addicted to your thoughts. Once the addiction is gone by being aware / conscious of your thoughts, you're free.
